title: What ASIC's 'sludge busting' shift means
text:
In a major about-face in the wake of the financial services royal commission, ASIC now concedes reams of disclosure such as prospectus statements, fact sheets and warnings have failed to protect consumers.

People don’t bother to read or don’t understand the endless words, which in some cases are intended to confuse, overwhelm or lull people into a false sense of security.

ASIC's move is a seismic shift from the foundations laid by the 1997 Wallis financial system inquiry which dictated that disclosure was the foundation of an efficient financial system.

The original idea was that as long as fine print was published, consumers could make informed choices in their own best interests.

But in a world of financial deregulation where consumers are drowned in choice, seeing endless colourful advertisements and offered thousands of complex financial products, many people struggle to sort the good from bad.

So in a post-Wallis era superseded by Kenneth Hayne’s royal commission, ASIC is now moving beyond disclosure and instead putting more onus on financial firms across banking, insurance, investment advice and superannuation.

ASIC insists “buyer beware” and personal responsibility have not been abandoned.

Nevertheless, it is tiptoeing towards a world of benevolent bureaucrats making more decisions about what is in people’s best financial interests.

Advertisement

ASIC will use new product intervention powers and design and distribution laws to force financial services providers to ditch unfair and risky financial products, and pressure advisers to provide simpler advice and to treat customers more fairly.

Shipton says ASIC’s “foundational” study, co-authored with the Netherlands Authority for the Financial Markets, is a “new frontier of regulation” and a “clarion call" for financial firms.

“If financial institutions and indeed regulators were to over rely on disclosure, we’re not going to get the consumer outcomes we need,” Shipton told a parliamentary committee in Canberra on Wednesday.

ASIC's Karen Chester at a parliamentary committee hearing in Canberra this month. Alex Ellinghausen

“We need to be embedding fairness into the financial system and avoiding harm.”

The regulatory shift, overseen by ASIC deputy chair and veteran public policy economist Karen Chester, has embraced behavioural economics to underpin the new regulatory toolkit.

It is a recognition financial markets are inherently complex, consumers have cognitive biases and firms compete for people's attention through advertising blitzes.

Chester says unnecessary complexity, or “sludge”, are getting in way of consumers making sensible decisions.

Advertisement

Liberal MP and free marketeer Jason Falinski “loves” behavioural economics and says “this is a massive step in the right direction by ASIC”.

But Falinksi also sees shortcomings, with ASIC edging away from personal responsibility to put more onus on firms.

“It’s not the role of the Parliament, the regulator or the corporation who can or cannot buy their product,” he says.

“Consumers need to have sovereignty over the decisions they make.”

'Not going far enough'

While applauding ASIC’s admission that disclosure has failed, he is also worried the regulator is not prepared to fully rip the Band-Aid off and is instead layering a new regime on top of the broken disclosure system.

“The issue is ASIC is not going far enough in sweeping disclosure away and it is building on top of a system that doesn’t work,” Falinski says.

Nevertheless, in a strange sort of way the embrace of consumer psychology in economic regulation is in line with Prime Minister Scott Morrison’s demands of the public service.

Advertisement

Morrison wants the bureaucracy to be less of an ivory tower, by delivering for Australians in practical ways and being responsive to how people behave in the real world.

This is an important first step in developing a truly human-centric solution. — Dilip Soman, University of Toronto

Dilip Soman, Canada research chair in behavioural science and economics at the University of Toronto, says many countries focus on disclosure and financial literacy for consumers, but "we should also think about a bit of human literacy for the financial services industry".

"This is an important first step in developing a truly human-centric solution," he says of ASIC's report.

Before Morrison was elevated to prime minister, the Behavioural Economics Team of the Australian Government inside the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet had been trying to “nudge” consumers and taxpayers towards their own interests.

There are 10 behavioural insights teams across the federal government, including at the Australian Taxation Office, the Health Department and ASIC.

A recent joint government-Westpac study found that repayments rose by about 28 per cent, or $134 on average, after 24,000 credit card holders received a text message reminding them that their bill was due. Email reminders had no effect.

Prime Minister and Cabinet deputy secretary David Gruen said in his Canada-Australia Public Policy Initiative Lecture in Ottawa last month that requiring financial advisers to disclose to their clients conflicts of interest such as product sales commissions should raise consumer suspicions of advice from conflicted advisers. It should provide an incentive for advisers to reduce or eliminate their conflicts of interest so their advice will be trusted.

Advertisement

But real-world behavioural economics suggests the issue runs much deeper.

Gruen cites the analysis of Cornell University psychologist Sunita Sah, whose work was commissioned by the Hayne royal commission and who has interacted with ASIC and the PM's department.

Sah found disclosures can cause clients to feel social pressure to follow conflicted advice. Clients can become concerned that declining to follow the advice would signal distrust in their adviser, with whom they have often formed a personal bond.

Sah tells AFR Weekend via email she is delighted ASIC is moving away from a heavy reliance on disclosure.

"Disclosures can paradoxically increase trust in the provider’s expertise, especially when consumers are distracted with competing information," she says.

"The opposite effect may also occur, in which disclosures make consumers sceptical and therefore prone to reject even high quality advice.

"Eliminating as many conflicts of interest as possible and aligning incentives for financial advisers and consumers will help improve advice quality and protect consumers."

The ASIC-Dutch regulator report found that when conflicted advisers gave bad advice and the conflict was disclosed, 81 per cent of people still followed the advice.

Advertisement

Among other key findings in the report, only two in five Australians given a key fact sheet for insurance objectively selected the best product, with 60 per cent picking suboptimal insurance.

Two-thirds of people were not able to locate all relevant investment fund fees and less than half could identify all super fund fees.

About 86 per cent of local consumers assessed the quality of financial advice to be good, in contrast to 39 per cent of the same advice being independently rated as poor.

And superannuation dashboards – intended to provide a simple snapshot summary of a super product on a fund's website – were found to be "vulnerable to manipulation".

Consumer choice could be “manipulated” by relabelling or reweighting asset allocation information used in diagrams, ASIC said.

At least in the case of complex financial services, the economic textbook theory of the rational consumer has been found wanting.
description: The regulator insists “buyer beware” has not been abandoned. But it is tiptoeing towards a world of benevolent bureaucrats making more decisions about what is in people’s best financial interests.
